awd_titl_txt: Conference: QLCI Leap Forward Career Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
Workforce development in quantum information science and engineering (QISE) is important for continued leadership in this emerging area, and for empowering high technology industries of the future. To explore and facilitate pathways for careers in QISE, this project will support a workshop. It will bring together graduate students and colleagues from a network of NSF-funded Quantum Leap Challenge Institutes (QLCI). There will be opportunities to engage with representatives from several dozen companies and potential employers in QISE related industries, and to discuss salient issues in career development for early professionals in QISE. Participants will build professional connections and relationships with peers that support workforce development and future collaborations for emerging scientists and engineers across the growing quantum ecosystem. 

The QLCI Leap Forward Career Conference is scheduled for April 11-12, 2024, in Chicago, Illinois. The first day will facilitate a larger number of QLCI student trainees from across the nation to participate in the Chicago Quantum Exchange 2024 Quantum Recruiting Forum. Both days will include QLCI-focused and student-focused programming to elucidate career pathways and strategies for career development in QISE-related areas.  Engagement with representatives from the Quantum Economic Development Consortium and representatives from several QLCI projects will provide participants with a broad range of perspectives and opportunities. The NSF conference grant will partially defray travel costs so that a larger number of QLCI trainees and students will have the opportunity to participate and build relationships with potential employers. Attendees will learn from quantum-focused industry professionals, faculty, researchers, and near peers (e.g., graduate students and postdocs). A key objective of the QLCI Leap Forward Career Conference is for QLCI students and trainees to advance their knowledge of professional and research opportunities within the QLCI network and in the broader ecosystem of quantum information science and engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The Quantum Leap Challenge Institute (QLCI) student and trainee community came together for a unique professional development opportunity at the NSF-funded Quantum Careers Workshop, hosted by the Hybrid Quantum Architectures and Networks (HQAN) QLCI on April 11–12, 2024. Over the course of two days and one night in Chicago, 29 students and trainees from all five QLCIs and 10 institutions participated in a series of events designed to connect them with quantum-focused employers and research opportunities. The workshop was built around the Chicago Quantum Recruiting Forum, where participants engaged in one-on-one meetings with industry professionals, networked with fellow researchers, and toured QLCI lab spaces. NSF support allowed the QLCI workforce and leadership teams to create an experience that not only advanced the careers of early-career scientists but also strengthened collaboration across the QLCI network.

By bringing together students, researchers, and employers, this event played a critical role in shaping career trajectories and strengthening connections within the quantum community across academy, industry, and national laboratories. The success of the 2024 Quantum Careers Workshop highlights the value of fostering professional networks and ensuring that students and early-career scientists have the resources and opportunities they need to thrive in the evolving quantum landscape.

Accomplishments

As an inaugural event, it is a significant accomplishment to have included participants from all five QLCIs, including a range of career levels (undergraduates, master’s students, Ph.D. candidates, and postdocs). The range of and interest from employers is also worth noting: 10 companies participated, including senior leaders, to meet with QLCI students and researchers. While it can be challenging to bring academy, industry, and national labs together, the Quantum Careers Workshop successfully connected.

Impact

Feedback from the workshop was overwhelmingly positive, with 95% of participants agreeing or strongly agreeing that they met other students and postdocs from outside their home institutions. Many cited one-on-one meetings with professionals, networking at the Quantum Recruiting Forum, and a dinner at Infleqtion as key highlights of the event. The impact of the workshop is already evident, as 21 of the 29 participants are still working toward degrees or continuing as postdoctoral researchers, while others have already taken the next step in their careers. One participant has moved into a postdoctoral research position at Tufts University, while six have transitioned to industry roles at companies such as Applied Materials, Quantum Circuits, Inc., JPMorganChase, QuEra, PsiQuantum, and Tokyo Electron US. Notably, two of those who entered industry—now employed at Applied Materials and JPMorganChase—met with their future employers at the Quantum Careers Workshop.

 


Last Modified: 03/15/2025
Modified by: Hannes Bernien
